file_content.text: You should return immediately to Special Forces Command on Coruscant. It's time we finished this.
I'll return to base immediately, General.
Copy that.
I'll see you soon, Lieutenant.
Do we have a lead on Tavus's position?
You mean Tavus?
I'm only coming back if it means putting a hole in Tavus's head.
This better be good.
We'll discuss the relevant intelligence when you arrive, Lieutenant. Do not delay.
Garza out.
Lieutenant, this is General Garza. Report: What is the status of your mission on Alderaan?
Everything's taken care of.
Mission accomplished, General.
You're just in time to congratulate me on a job well done, General.
Successful, as always.
I'm pleased to hear that, Lieutenant. Congratulations.
And what of Gearbox? What is his current status?
Gearbox has been dealt with, as ordered.
Objective neutralized.
Gearbox refused to surrender--I had to kill him.
I'm afraid he's dead.
Understood--if you had no choice, then you had no choice.
I took that old man out without breaking a sweat.
He was an easy kill.
If your given task wasn't challenging enough, more difficult ones can easily be found.
Let's just say you can cross Gearbox off the list.
Another day, another kill.
Excellent, Lieutenant. Top-notch work.
Now, regarding your secondary objective--assisting House Organa wherever possible.
A very angry young man named Pallos claims that you caused House Organa a great deal of trouble. Please elaborate.
Pallos repeatedly interfered with my mission, General. I did nothing to provoke him.
That's a lie!
Really, Lieutenant? I suspected he wasn't being entirely accurate, but perhaps there was some kernel of truth in what he said...?
Pallos didn't like me cutting deals with his prisoner.
Just ignore him.
Yes, he made that much quite clear.
That idiot impeded my mission from the beginning, General.
Pallos is a fool.
You struck him, Lieutenant! An unarmed civilian ally of the Republic!
Perhaps so, Lieutenant, but there are certain niceties to be observed when dealing with our allies.
You got Gearbox, as ordered. Your success is undisputed.
But our allies are critical to the war effort. You will be more diplomatic in the future. Understood?
This won't happen again, sir--I promise.
Understood, General.
I would appreciate that very much.
Cut me a break, all right?
Take it easy.
The enemy will never "cut us a break," Lieutenant. That is why our allies are so important.
You want diplomacy, send a diplomat.
What am I, an ambassador?
You are an officer in the Army of the Galactic Republic, Lieutenant. You must learn to be more than a simple grunt.
Pallos Organa tells me you conducted yourself with utmost courtesy and were an invaluable operative on his house's behalf.
I'm glad to hear Pallos was so pleased.
I do my best.
So was I.
Pallos is just happy I let him keep his prisoner.
We came to an understanding.
Then doing so was a wise move on your part, Lieutenant. Well done.
Do me a favor--never make me work with any nobles again.
These nobles were ridiculous.
No promises, Lieutenant. Especially since you seem to be quite good at it.
With Gearbox eliminated, you have officially dealt with every Havoc traitor outpost we are aware of. But, as you know, our task is not yet complete.
I believe there is work to be done elsewhere. I'll not delay you any further.
Garza out.
Lieutenant, thank you for calling. From what I hear, you've been very busy. We have quite a bit to discuss.
First, congratulations on stopping the bombings in Anchorhead. Mayor Klerren was both impressed and grateful. Well done.
Glad I could make a difference.
Thank you, General.
You've represented the Republic very well in this. Good job.
These Rim-rats are easy to impress.
It was no big deal.
True. But good work is good work, regardless.
This whole town would be gone if not for me.
The mayor is lucky I was here.
So I heard.
I also understand that you not only located Fuse, but routed an entire Imperial research facility in the process.
Lieutenant Tasser filed his report only moments ago, actually. I'm sorry he and his men couldn't arrive sooner.
Lieutenant Tasser was very helpful, General.
No problem.
I'm glad to hear it.
I can handle these missions on my own.
Their help wasn't necessary.
That was Lieutenant Tasser's estimation as well. Still, I prefer to have backup available to you whenever possible.
Recon punks. Give me real fighting men or don't bother.
Next time, send real soldiers.
The Forty-third are an exemplary squad.
Tasser described the Imperial facility as a "flaming graveyard." And I understand Fuse was among the deceased.
I'll admit, I'm a bit confused by that turn of events. According to Mayor Klerren, Fuse cooperated and was instrumental in your operation.
The Imperial base was rigged to detonate. Fuse insisted I leave him behind to stop Gorik.
Fuse sacrificed himself.
That was... very noble of him.
Fuse gave his life so that I could stop Gorik. And... he asked me to tell you he was sorry.
He felt awful for his actions.
I... see.
It's all such a pity. He was a good soldier.
You didn't send me here to make friends. I did my job--nothing more.
Orders are orders.
I couldn't risk that guy walking around.
Fuse was too dangerous.
You are permitted to take prisoners, Lieutenant. Fuse might have been useful to have alive.
You shouldn't take some civi's word over mine.
Klerren was easily duped.
I'm not, Lieutenant--and I'd appreciate a more respectful tone. A superior officer is permitted to question her soldiers regarding mission outcomes.
What about the bomb designs that Fuse created for the Imperials? Were you able to retrieve a copy?
Yes, General.
Fuse died to make sure we got these designs.
These came at a heavy cost.
Then we'd best make good use of them. I'll download them to Coruscant for review.
Fuse's designs are pretty nasty--the Imps won't know what hit them.
Let's put these bombs to use.
Excellent, Lieutenant. I'll download them to Coruscant for review.
The Imperials fled with the designs while I was saving Fuse.
No, General, I couldn't.
I'm glad you managed to bring Fuse in alive, Lieutenant, but letting those designs slip away will carry a heavy cost.
The Imperials escaped with the designs.
No, General, I couldn't.
Disappointing. Those designs could be devastating in Imperial hands.
You sent me to hunt traitors, not bomb designs.
My objective was Fuse.
Serving the Republic war effort is always a primary objective, Lieutenant.
The designs took a hit during the fighting.
[Lie.] They were destroyed.
Try to shoot more carefully in the future, Lieutenant. Those designs would have been very useful.
With Tatooine dealt with, you've now dealt with every Havoc traitor outpost we're aware of. But as you know, the task is still incomplete.
Still, you've now successfully dealt with every Havoc traitor outpost we're aware of. But there is still work to be done.
I have nothing further for you, Lieutenant. Carry on with your mission, and keep up the good work. Garza out.
Copy that.
Time to get off this worthless rock.
It's good to be leaving.
I'm still waiting for some kind of commendation, Garza.
Why don't we talk advancement?
A matter for another time, Lieutenant.
Garza out.
Still, your mission was largely successful; you are to be congratulated.
Tasser reports that you brought Fuse in alive and without resistance.
Kardan will be pleased. He had begun to doubt our commitment to bring the Havoc traitors in safely.
Fuse's expertise will no doubt be very useful. Taking him alive was a smart move. Expertly done.
I never could've pulled this off without him.
Fuse was extremely helpful.
Yes, Mayor Klerren indicated that as well. I'm pleased that Fuse could see the error of his ways.
I wish I could've nailed that scum Gorik before he ran off.
The Imps got away, though.
Ah. That is troubling, Lieutenant. Still, Fuse was by far the most important objective.
Not much we could've done with his corpse.
He was just more useful alive.
All too true, Lieutenant.
Lieutenant! Report--were you able to neutralize Tavus?
I'm afraid Tavus wasn't at the coordinates.
Negative, General.
I see. I take it he left you something for your trouble, though.
No Tavus--just the Shadow Fist.
It was all just a setup.
Incredible. Ambushed by the Empire's best, and still standing.
This whole thing was a trap, and you sent me straight into it!
You got me ambushed!
I sent you to do your job. Get ahold of yourself.
I'm sorry, Lieutenant. I wouldn't have sent you if I'd known it was a ruse, but there was no way to be sure.
Ambushes are just part of the job.
No need to apologize, General.
Tavus should've known his trap wouldn't kill me.
This was a desperate attempt.
Perhaps so. But the fact that he went to so much trouble to arrange a trap just for you says a great deal.
I don't send people into dangerous situations lightly, Lieutenant. It's a relief to see you survive in spite of the odds against you.
You'd better be more careful in the future.
I don't want excuses.
I am your commanding officer, Lieutenant--do not tell me how to do my job.
What about the prototype cloaking device? Were you able to retrieve it, or did Tavus manage to sneak that away from us as well?
The prototype is secure, General.
I have the package.
Excellent work. The people in R & D would never have forgiven us if we hadn't retrieved it.
This device would be very useful in my missions.
Can I keep it?
Forget it. That prototype will be transferred directly to R & D as soon as you land in a Republic-friendly port.
I almost died to get this stupid hunk of metal.
You'd better appreciate this.
You retrieved a military asset of incredible importance in the face of extreme danger. You did well.
Our only choice now is to proceed as originally planned. Our technicians have determined your final two target locations: Tatooine and Alderaan.
I'll give you a full briefing when you arrive at each mission zone. Move out immediately. Garza out.
We've found another lead, regarding Tavus. Something very promising.
At this point, we must carry on with your mission as originally planned. One world remains to be searched--proceed there immediately.
Come in, Lieutenant--this is General Garza. I have a priority one assignment for you. It's Tavus.
He and a team of commandos just raided a Republic research center on Cularin and stole a prototype cloaking device.
But the prototype contains a tracking beacon. We now know the exact location of Tavus's ship. This is it, Lieutenant.
I can move on Tavus's position immediately, General.
I'm ready.
Why would Tavus go after this cloaking device?
Tell me about the prototype.
The device renders an entire capital ship invisible--visually and to sensors. The advantage it would offer the Empire is obvious.
I have doubts, sir.
Let's hope the situation really is as simple as it appears.
Tavus's ship is currently sitting alone in an empty sector of space--most likely waiting to rendezvous with a larger vessel. You have to get there before that happens, Lieutenant.
Understood.
Do we have a backup plan in case I don't reach the coordinates in time?
What if I don't make it?
When I hear "lone ship in empty space," I think "trap."
Sounds like an ambush to me.
We'll deal with that situation if it occurs. But we have to take this chance.
This is Harron Tavus himself, Lieutenant. Succeed here, and everything else becomes an afterthought.
You can count on me, sir.
That's why I'm sending you.
What are my orders, General? Capture or neutralize?
You want him alive or dead?
He could be useful to us alive... but take no chances. We cannot afford to let Tavus escape.
Get my medal ready. This is going to be one for the records.
I'd better get recognition.
You can worry about medals after the job is done.
Be sure to secure the prototype cloaking device after you've dealt with Tavus. If it fell into the Empire's hands, it could be... disastrous.
I'm transmitting the coordinates to you now. Effect entry to Tavus's ship, then do whatever is necessary to neutralize him and retrieve the prototype. Good hunting--Garza out.
Ah. Lieutenant. There you are.
Do I need to reiterate my disappointment in your decision to intentionally disobey orders and reveal the SpecForce defections to the SIS? Or has that been made suitably clear?
Clear, General. It won't happen again.
No need to repeat yourself.
I'm glad to hear it.
Jonas needed to know the full situation, General.
I did the right thing.
Agent Balkar knew all he needed to assist you.
I accomplished my mission. That should be all that matters.
I don't care if you're happy.
I give orders for a reason, Lieutenant. Keeping these defections a secret is critical.
As for the mission itself, I am satisfied. You've stopped Tavus's plans for the M1-4X and returned a valuable asset to Republic service. Well done.
I'm pleased that you avoided revealing the defections to Agent Balkar. Hiding information from the SIS is hardly a simple task.
Just following orders, General.
It was no problem.
We shouldn't be hiding the facts from our allies.
I didn't like it.
I understand, Lieutenant, but I gave the order for a good reason. You'll have to trust me.
It wasn't easy stringing Jonas along, but I managed.
That spy pushed hard.
Yes, he was much more clever than I anticipated.
I'm also very pleased with the outcome of the mission itself. M1-4X is back where he belongs--well done.
I'm glad you approve, General.
Thank you.
This was an easy one.
Until I have Tavus in my sights, I won't be satisfied.
It's still not Tavus himself.
Neither will I, Lieutenant. But that's only a matter of time.
I understand you also performed some skillful negotiating. Very impressive.
I'm just glad we avoided any major incidents.
It was a tense situation.
You aren't the only one.
Me and the Imps are all good buddies now.
It was fun!
Mm. It would be best if you didn't joke about that.
Cutting deals with the enemy isn't what I signed up for.
I won't be doing that again.
The circumstances weren't right for a direct attack, so you adapted. That's good soldiering.
Of course, you did almost plunge the entire galaxy into a war just to accomplish this mission. Please try to avoid that sort of thing in the future.
I'll try to be more careful from now on.
Understood.
Imperials are the enemy. I shoot the enemy.
I don't negotiate.
The Imperials shot first, General. I had to defend myself.
It wasn't my fault!
Ah. Well, next time, try not to defend yourself so extensively in such a public place.
I signed up to fight, not to negotiate.
Aw, you're no fun.
The Treaty of Coruscant still stands, at least nominally. We can't be seen initiating public hostilities.
Now--I've just received some intelligence that I want Havoc to act on immediately. It's Tavus.
That's all I have for you, Lieutenant. You may proceed with your next assignment.
Garza out.
Unfortunately, Lieutenant, your work on Nar Shaddaa isn't done--another situation has developed.
Lieutenant. I assume Sergeant Dorne took the news well?
Sergeant Dorne is honored to be in Havoc Squad.
That's right.
She's joining the best unit in the galaxy. She was ecstatic.
What do you think?
Excellent. We'll have the squad fully restaffed in no time.
I'm still not thrilled about having an Imp in my squad, General.
Better than I did, at least.
You don't have to be thrilled. And I think it might go better for you if you avoid calling her an "Imp."
One other detail: Were you able to retrieve a sample of the weaponized rakghoul disease that Needles was developing?
I did.
Excellent. Just leave it in the secured case beneath the holocommunicator. I'll see that it reaches research division.
I'd hate to think of the Republic using it on anyone.
We won't use this, will we?
Enjoy your horrifying biological weapon, General.
It's all yours.
Research purposes only, I assure you. Just leave it in the secured case beneath the holocommunicator; I'll see it reaches the right people.
No samples were retrieved, General.
Negative.
Needles' work was horrifying. No one will ever get their hands on it again.
I destroyed the samples.
That was foolish, Lieutenant. Those samples could've been invaluable for the war effort.
The last sample took a stray blaster bolt while I was dealing with Needles.
It was destroyed in the fight.
That's too bad. Research division would've done anything to get their hands on a sample, and I could've used the favors.
Now--a new situation has just developed that requires your immediate intervention. It's Tavus.
That's all for now, Lieutenant. Congratulations once again. Garza out.
Nothing further. Try not to be so wasteful of our opportunities in the future. Garza out.
At any rate, another situation has developed on Nar Shaddaa that requires immediate intervention.
In any event, another situation has developed on Nar Shaddaa that requires your immediate intervention.
Ah, Lieutenant. I was just speaking with Sergeant Jaxo. Congratulations.
Saving Senator Krasul will certainly help our affairs with the Senate. We needed someone to owe us a favor--well done.
Thank you, General.
You've accomplished something very important--something beyond even your assignment to hunt down Tavus and the other traitors.
I'm not sure Krasul will be taking our side on anything.
Don't get too excited.
In the end, he will remember who saved his life--and that's very important for us.
Don't waste my time with politics.
Spare me.
The politics come with the job--the sooner you get that through your head, the better.
You're in the field, Lieutenant... you see how far the Empire is reaching. A full attack isn't far off, now.
To keep the Empire's forces at bay, we need the Senate's support. We need allies.
I'm glad I could help out the cause.
Allies are good.
Yes, you've done quite well in that regard.
I only kept Krasul alive to get his support.
That's why I saved him.
I'm not sure I want to hear that, but I'm glad that you at least understand the situation.
Why doesn't the Senate just let us do our job?
I hate politics.
Politicians meddle--it's in their nature. So it's up to us to limit that meddling as best we can.
One thing, Lieutenant, I was disappointed to learn of Wraith's escape. She's capable of causing great turmoil.
You have my apologies, General--it won't happen again.
I'm sorry.
No, I'm sure it won't.
Catching Wraith would have meant leaving Krasul to die.
There was nothing I could do.
Then you probably made the best choice. The Senator is certainly more useful alive than dead.
When I catch Wraith, she's going to wish she had died.
She won't escape long.
I have little doubt.
Lieutenant--I'm glad you called. I'm not sure what to make of Sergeant Jaxo's report.
Taking down Wraith was an important objective, and I'm glad you did so. But how could you fail to save Senator Krasul beforehand?
I made a mistake, General. It won't happen again.
I'm sorry.
At least Wraith is no longer a threat.
Defusing the bombs around Krasul would've tipped Wraith off and given her a chance to flee.
I had to sacrifice him.
Lieutenant, you let a Senator die just to complete an objective--this is a dangerous path to tread.
I ran into Wraith before I found the Senator--that's it.
[Lie.] It was just bad luck.
I see. That's some very bad luck, indeed, Lieutenant.
While I'm pleased you were able to neutralize Wraith, allowing a Senator to die... this is a very dangerous line to tread.
I've failed you, General.
I'm sorry.
We'll see. You may have made the right choice, in the long run. It's difficult to know.
Wraith was too dangerous to leave alive.
There was no other choice.
The life of a Senator of the Republic, against the innocent lives Wraith would have taken later. It's a tough call.
Kill the Havoc traitors at any cost--that's my mission.
Just following orders.
True, but the ultimate purpose of the mission is to safeguard the Republic, and I'm not sure that letting a Senator die is in line with that.
I won't claim to miss Senator Krasul's... involvement, in our affairs. But his death will not be easy to explain away.
Why not tell the truth, General?
Why explain it away?
You always manage.
Our secrecy is an absolute necessity. Do not dismiss it.
We're Special Forces. We shouldn't have to explain ourselves, General.
I don't care who knows.
Politics are a necessary part of our greater goal.
The Empire will eventually strike at us in force--probably sooner than later.
SpecForce needs to be operating at its fullest. A large-scale Senate investigation would distract us. Waste resources. Cost lives.
I'll be more careful in the future.
Understood.
Be careful, but never be afraid to do your job.
I'll do my job, you do yours, General.
I don't need a lecture.
Gladly. Just remember that recklessness on your part can render my job impossible.
It's important to hide the truth, because the truth will get you fired. Isn't that right?
You're just covering yourself.
It might, and it might not. But any time I spend fighting for my position is time I could spend fighting the enemy.
But this is a theoretical discussion. I still have my job, which means that you will still obey my orders.
Now--our technicians have decoded the first two sets of data from the Coruscant relay. Your first two targets are on Taris and Nar Shaddaa.
Taris and Nar Shaddaa--I'll move out right away.
Copy that.
Can you tell me anything beyond the destinations?
Any details?
Not at this time, I'm afraid. I'll try to collect more intelligence and give you a fuller briefing when you arrive at each location.
Don't you think I'm due for some time off?
More, already?
Our enemies aren't taking time off, so neither can we.
Good luck. Garza out.
Now--our technicians have decoded more data from the Coruscant relay. Your next two targets are on Tatooine and Alderaan.
Tatooine and Alderaan--I'll move out immediately, General.
Copy that.
Proceed to the given coordinates and intercept Tavus immediately, Lieutenant.
A Republic Senator named Krasul has been taken hostage. You may remember Krasul from the "informal hearing" that you attended here on Coruscant.
Krasul was the one who doubted everything I said.
Yes, I remember him.
Unsurprising. You aren't the first SpecForce operator to have had the pleasure of such a conversation.
I'm afraid I don't remember him, sir.
Not coming to mind.
Male Cathar. Large, heavyset build. I'll have an image sent to you.
Bureaucrats aren't worth remembering, sir.
One of those jerks, huh?
Ordinarily, I'd agree, but this bureaucrat is particularly significant.
Senator Krasul and his oversight committee have been involved in the activities of SpecForce Division for years, so his kidnapper's identity comes as no surprise: Wraith.
How do you know it's Wraith, sir?
Are you sure?
Of all the holocams on Coruscant, only two saw the kidnapping--but Wraith was easily identified.
Who?
Wraith. The former Havoc Squad assassin. One of your targets.
If you ask me, Wraith is doing us a favor.
Let her have the guy.
Lieutenant, we may not always agree with the Senate, but they're still the sovereign body of the Republic.
Wraith managed to slip Krasul offworld. Tracking her down has been very difficult.
But luckily, you're still in the area. Wraith is holding the Senator hostage inside a warehouse in the Red Light Sector.
Is Jonas going to be my contact for this assignment as well?
Will I work with the SIS again?
No. A SpecForce team carried out preliminary reconnaissance. They will rendezvous at your ship within a few minutes.
However, a few moments ago we learned that she is holding the Senator in a warehouse on Nar Shaddaa--an area known as the Red Light Sector.
Will I have any backup in the field? Supplies? Comms?
What are my assets?
A team is already in the field, Lieutenant. You'll be met at the spaceport with further details and support information.
Is Wraith running solo, or does she have backup?
Tell me about the opposition.
Our team on the ground confirmed Imperial troops are guarding the warehouse.
Sounds to me like Wraith just kidnapped the Senator to use as bait.
I smell a trap.
The possibility exists--especially given what we know about the warehouse itself.
Aside from Wraith and Krasul, scans detected large amounts of baradium explosives inside the warehouse. Use great caution, Lieutenant.
Understood.
All part of your mission parameters.
I'll be very careful.
I knew you'd be the best choice for this mission.
I'm sure Sergeant Jorgan will scout things out thoroughly.
Jorgan can go first!
Great. What an honor.
I'm sure it's nothing Sergeant Dorne can't handle.
Elara can go first!
With respect, sir, I lack the T-7A certification required to carry out a bomb defusal.
This will be the perfect chance for M1-4X to show us what he's made of.
Forex can go first!
My layered durasteel-polymer plates are highly resistant to all manner of explosives. I will perform this task with great pride!
Your subordinates do not exist to be fodder for the enemy, Lieutenant.
Leave the op details to me, all right?
Just let me do my job.
If your mission plan is unaffected by the presence of volatile high explosives, then I have serious doubts about your mission plan.
Now hurry. Senator Krasul must be rescued before Wraith can complete whatever it is she's hoping to achieve. Garza out.
